title: International Transport Forum (ECMT)
segmentation: Well, good afternoon everybody and thank you very much chairman for the introduction and for giving the opportunity to tell you a bit about the research that we undertake at the Joint Transport Center of the OECD and the international transp.
Forum.
I want to say very briefly, something about who we are, what our work looks like, the partnerships that we're involved in, and finally ministerial that we're organizing.

Next month, now we're in international governmental organization, So what we're concerned with is trying to bring the results of both technical and Economic Research to the policy making community to the decision makers and try to bridge what is sometimes seems to be an extremely wide gap between what the research community knows and what the policy makers are doing.
Um?
Now the OECD, I think, is extremely familiar with joint because we are 50% financed by the Oecd's budget, and 50% financed by the International Transport Forum.
Now the ITF was created or recreated a year ago, out of the European Conference of Ministers of Transport, which the CMT which may be familiar to more of you.
Reason it changed was because it's now got the same membership coverage as the OECD plus all of the Central and Eastern European countries that we had in the CMT.
As far as Russia.
So the US, Japan, Australia and so on very much actively engaged in both parts of the operation now.
With supervised by a research committee which is peopled by ministries of transport, representatives of Ministries of Transport directly and also by transport research.
Agencies dependent on the ministries.
We chat at the moment by Canada by Richard TV hours from Transport Canada.
On the Secretariat side, we work for our Director, Jack Shaw, who's also Secretary General of the International Transport Forum.
We have a staff of 10 people in the center and there's a further 16 people in the.
Sport forum.

Now, our research agencies on the committee cover a wide range of countries from Australia and France where we have agencies that cover the whole range of transport is in issues some more specialized, like suave in the Netherlands, looking at Rd safety and down to the USA, where the Federal Highways Agency and reach are both involved and the deoti more general.
Our work, I mean the committee is, is responsible for determining the work that we do, and they have the hard job that was described by era Rd.
Then of determining what we do, why we do it, and how we do it.
And we are increasingly trying to evaluate what we do, trying to fine tune what we do.
But basically the decisions are taken by the committee.
Work is currently organized around 4 strategic themes.
Infrastructure and operations safety and security globalization and the spatial impacts of transport and planning.
And Environmental Protection.
And the projects are chosen within these four strategic themes.
And they delivered a by a variety of different project vehicles depending on the nature of the work.

The core work is done by working groups which bring experts from the member government departments and agencies who typically work for 2 1/2 years together and end their work with the publication of a report.

We have shorter term, more focused work organized around Roundtables which last for a day and a half and pick the best minds in the academic research area to really thrash out each specific issues haunt house over a day and a half around a small number of papers and shared by a leading figure in that particular area.

We have other kinds of conferences that we hold from time to time, mainly to disseminate the results for work every three years we have a bigger event, a symposium, which is like a very mini tiare on a specific theme, and we maintain statistical databases.

Just to give you a flavor of one or two of these things, next symposium will be held in Madrid from the 16th to 19th of November, very generously organized by Celtics and by the Ministry of Transport Fermento in Spain.

The theme overarching theme will be the future for interurban passenger transport looking particularly markets that competition and the regulation of potential market power, but also looking at some of these other aspects.
We have room for 350 participants or a little bit more.
We hope to see those of you who are working in these areas coming to Madrid.
This is a quick preview.
There's nothing on our website at the moment for you to register, but in the next couple of months we will have some.
Sing up.
A few words about our roundtables.
These are quite inflexible vehicle.

We've started to organize them increasingly around preparations for annual ministerial that's held on the on the forum side, the first one in preparation for our ministerial on climate change, which will happen in a months time looking at the cost and the effectiveness of emissions regulation and trying to get down into the theoretical and opinions underpinnings for the instruments that are being developed at the moment in terms of carbon taxes and vehicle.

Regulations and the more you look, the more surprising it is how little the judgments are based on empirical data and how much still reposes on political judgment of the size of the market failures on the one hand versus the costs of action on the other.

The other four roundtables listed up there looking into the future of preparing for our 2009 ministerial that will be looking at globalization and trade and investment needs that result for transport.

Again, any of you that are particularly interested in airline and airport competition security risk perception, cost, benefit assessment, and vertical integration of transport and logistics chains, and what that means for potential market power.
Don't hesitate to get in touch with me.
It could be good to have you participating in some of these events.

Word on a couple of our recent work working group programs just completed the first transport infrastructure investment was chaired by Urban Carlstrom, who was the CEO of VTi at the time and has since moved to advise.

The finance minister in Sweden on precisely the issues that we covered centering alternative financing models for transport infrastructure, particularly PPS, and looking at the advantages on the one hand and the potential risks on the other, and a lot of our work looks at how the public sector should be managing the risks involved with technology and particularly economics.
And then the second project I wanted to mention it was chaired by Jorgen Christiansen, who's sitting just down here on the front row on long life services for heavy traffic roads.
We have a session tomorrow in room M2.

Somewhere in this building from three to five where we're looking at taking the work that we've done so far in collaboration, particularly with eight laboratories around the world, including the US in New Zealand on testing, 2 very promising new materials.

We want this now to proceed to a full field trial, stay off stage and we hope the workshop tomorrow will enable this to be launched with the collaboration of the European Commission and particularly with.
Who's playing a very key role in this?
One last event later this year on Rd Safety.

For those of you working in that area, we want to bring the results of a whole series of work we've done over the last couple of years, looking particularly at how to put ambitious targets for Rd safety improvements into fruition.
Building around a safe system approach an here again, getting the political community to understand where researchers taken to us in terms of safe system approaches.
And that's on the 25th and the 26th of September in Paris.
Now we supposed to say something about research collaboration, and that's difficult to say in a way that is digestible.
We do a lot of cooperation with a lot of organizations, and lot of them represented here today.
And you can see some of the examples on here.
There's no means exhaustive.
Work towards the bottom with Phil.
Actually track is very much just developing now, particularly the last two organizations which are relatively recent.
What I need to say I think really, is that we are very small.
We have an annual budget of 2 million euros only.

A role is to bring the researchers in our member countries together to pull their own work and to draw conclusions for policy making in a way that supports their work at home in a mutually beneficial way.
And I'm acutely aware that we depend on the expertise and the goodwill of quite a small group of individuals to work with us to achieve this.
So our first job is to make this cooperation as easy and as pleasant as possible.
And we're fortunate to have some very good administrators who are able to do this and bring their own expertise to fill in gaps that are missing in the teams that we set up.
And I know that all our networks draw on pretty much the same small group of individuals, inevitably.
So it's up to us also to work very closely together to make sure that we make things easy.
And by and large that works well.
Of course, we can't always cover all the bases.
We miss things that are going on in other people's work but lion large.
It works well, and I'm very grateful for the help that I get from the other organisations from attract further from here and that and from European Commission officials.

Are you willing to leave some room for this guy out by closing with just two slides on our ministerial forum at the end of May, which will be devoted to transport and energy and the challenge of climate change?
You're all very welcome to participate in it and to try and get a chance to participate in the panels of ministers drawing the forum.
Registrations open on the web.
The first day will be devoted to an exchange between research and industry, organized around 4 workshops.
The first on vehicle technologies, the second on emerging economies, and the other two on freight and passenger transport, respectively.

And then the second day will have a series of political panels where the chairs from each of the workshops will participate to try and bring the results of those discussions and all the work that we've done over the last couple of years.
In preparing for it.
To the decision makers.
And that chairmans it.
You can find information on what I've said at our website, which is just our name.
It's a bit long, but it's easy enough to remember.
Or by contacting me directly at that email address.
Thank you.
Is very much.
